fields.Title of Contribution: Gauging Risk and Protective Factors Contributing to e-Cigarette Use Among Multiracial Youth
fields.Description/Abstract: <span>Background: </span><span>Currently, e</span><span>-</span><span>cigarettes are the most common form of nicotine consumption among youth in the United </span><span>States. There is a lack of research focusing on e</span><span>-</span><span>cigarette use among multiracial youth, yet the sparse literature points </span><span>toward the adverse consequences of e</span><span>-</span><span>cigarettes on multiracial youth. Multiracial youth tend to have higher addiction </span><span>and prevalence rates of e</span><span>-</span><span>cigarette use compared to other racial/ethnic groups. The current research focuses on </span><span>analyzing e</span><span>-</span><span>cigarette use based on parental factors, school factors, prosocial behavior, ease of access, risk behaviors, </span><span>perception of harm, and sociodemographic differences among multiracial youth. </span><span>Methods:</span><span> A secondary data analysis of the 2020 Student Drug Use Survey (N</span><span>=</span><span>38</span><span>048) was performed. Of these, </span><span>n</span><span>=</span><span>3340 self</span><span>-</span><span>identified as multiracial. Descriptive analysis, univariate logistic regression, and logistic regression were </span><span>performed. </span><span>Results: </span><span>Results indicate that the odds of using e</span><span>-</span><span>cigarettes among multiracial youth increase 2 times when not </span><span>perceived as harmful, 2 times if one is employed, 18 times if involved in high</span><span>-</span><span>risk behaviors, and 2 times if in 9th through </span><span>12th grade. Additionally, logistic regression demonstrates that parental factors may not be significant in e</span><span>-</span><span>cigarette use </span><span>among multiracial youth. </span><span>Conclusion: </span><span>It is crucial to investigate the association between e</span><span>-</span><span>cigarette use and multiracial youth, as they may </span><span>be disproportionately affected by chronic conditions and fatal diseases linked to tobacco use. Understanding the specific </span><span>risk and protective factors influencing e</span><span>-</span><span>cigarette use within this demographic can help design targeted interventions, </span><span>particularly for multiracial youth in the Greater Cincinnati region.</span>
